author: Stephanie R. Roberts
title: Frustrating - stick with the original Clue
content:
This game is no less "complex" than the original Clue game, and it's much less fun to play.  It's too easy to accidentally see the clues; they're on the bases of the character and furniture tokens and are visible if (when) one gets tipped over.  I gave it two stars only because there are a couple of situations where it would be more appropriate than the original.  First, a non-reader would be able to play, they just need to be able to recognize numbers for the time element.  Second, it doesn't involve a murder mystery.  The plot of Clue Junior is to uncover who ate the piece of cake at what time and with what beverage.  My son is almost seven, though, and I'm not too concerned that he's going to turn to a life of crime as the Lead Pipe Killer.  In general, I'd pass on this game.

(Tip: if you're choosing this option b/c your child has trouble holding the cards for the regular game, Iook for a card holder for kids - there are plenty on Amazon.)

author: Emily96
title: Fun game but we had to modify the rules and the notepad runs out quickly and is unavailable for purchase
content: Overall it's a fun game and my 4 year old loves it, but there are some drawbacks. The purpose of the game is to find out 1.) Who ate the cake, 2.) What time they ate the cake, and 3.) What they drank. You find out 1 and 2 by looking under the suspect/character pieces and 3 by looking underneath the furniture pieces located in specific rooms. There are Time/Drink tiles you shuffle and place randomly under each Character/Furniture game piece so there is a different solution each game. (One Time and one Drink tile go into the middle of the board for the players to figure out by process of elimination and the "crumb" tile gets shuffled with the time tiles and randomly assigned to a character who becomes the cake villain). Here is what I think is the biggest drawback - Unlike regular Clue, each player is not supposed to "be" a character. Instead, on your turn you are supposed to move whichever character piece you wish. This can cause frustration because you can only look under a character piece by either rolling a white square on the dice, or landing on one of only 3 white spaces on the entire game board. As you keep trying to move specific character pieces to get into a certain room (to get to one of the 3 spots where you can look under them) the other players can also keep moving the piece you need on their turns and it's futile. It makes it really hard to figure out the Who and the Time. This led to us always figure the Drink first and spending the last 2/3s of the game trying to look under the people to figure out the time and cake eater. We modified the rules so each player picked one designated character piece to play/move and when they landed on one of the 3 white spaces on the board to allow you to look under a character, they could look under any character they choose, not just the one they moved. It improved the game greatly. Another small drawback - My four year old LOVES this game, but there are some drawbacks with that too. One of the nice things for small children about this game compared to regular Clue is that the notepad has pictures for each character and beverage instead of text so my 4 year old can play on her own and unassisted check off the items on her notepad using the pictures. The three of us have probably played this game 30x since Christmas, and we are now out of notepads, and guess what - they don't sell any more! So if you plan on this game lasting long term it's not going to make it.

author: John Graham
title: Different than adult game but definitely fun when you get the hang of it
content: This game's strategy is different than the adult version, but is still very enjoyable.  You set it up by putting 1 time and 1 drink (unknown by all) in the middle. Then mix up the rest of the pieces and put the people and room objects in the correct stands and place them in the correct places.  The tricky part for adults is that you aren't one specific player - you can move any of the pieces around.  It can get frustrating when you little one moves someone you have been trying to get some place, but that's part of the strategy too so adults still have to stay on their toes in figuring stuff out.  My daughter is 5 and loves playing this game. She has gotten quite good at her strategy now and often beats me to the punch.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Five Stars
content: Great family friendly game!

author: Nathan S.
title: Cute take on a classic!
content:
Our 5 year old had a lot of fun playing this game with us. It was nice to have a kid friendly mystery to solve instead of the murder in the original. The character pieces are fun and the rules easy to learn.

There are 2 downsides:
1) the board needs to be bigger. Pieces were often to crowded causing both the kids and adults to repeatedly knock pieces over when moving another.

2) there are white tokens that you shuffle and put under the characters. They are annoying to try and move with the characters as they are thin and hard to grab. If you flip them and try to stick the character bases into them they repeatedly fall off, exposing the clue if they flip when falling off.

author: SW2018
title: A PERFECT family game to introduce kids to logic and reasoning
content: My daughter loves this game. I was skeptical because some people have criticized the game. It's not as complex as the original CLUE, but for a child, it's perfect to introduce them to the basic concept of logic games. This has helped build up her understanding of how to work out a logic puzzle and we're about to introduce the regular game of CLUE. That being said, she LOVES the figures in this game and enjoys it every time we play it. Adults may get bored with it after a while, but it's not supposed to be a game for adults. It's for families with kids. And it's perfect for that purpose.

title: Great for a range of ages.

I did not have high hopes as despite my best efforts, board games seem to get a couple plays and then quickly lose interest from my kids.  My kids (9 and 5) have actually been requesting to play this though!  With my older child I will play against them but when the 5 year old is playing we work together to solve the mystery and they love it.  The set up can be a little confusing and takes a few minutes, but other than that a great game.

author: Amazon Customer
title: This game is perfect for younger children
content: This game is perfect for younger children.  It has all the fun of the traditional Clue game, however instead of solving a murder mystery you are trying to discover who ate the last piece of cake.  Although geared towards younger children, we found that this game also works very well for our Autistic son.  He is older than the targeted age range for this game, but having a less complicated and time restricting version of the game allows him to participate in family game nights.

author: Ethan
title: Game "(re)design" Disaster
content:
DON'T BUY!!!

 Bought new was wrapped in plastic and is missing white peices because they where meant to hold characters which are now plastic figures. The idea behind the white peices was to create random play each game but with the new plastic figures with the stickers it creates a bit of a permanent problem as it can no longer be random every game. We will more than likely fix this problem by using pennies. The dice is also missing so we couldn't even play, which was a big let down as this was a gift from my 4 year old daughter to her daddy for father's day. It sounds like Hasbro needs to take these off the shelf make some changes and finish (re)designing their game!

No issue at all with Amazon shipping was stellar as always, my only thought would be to take it off Amazon all togeather because the game is unplayable as is!

author: Sarh
title: Game isn't playable as packaged
content: Hasbro seems to have revised the game but didn't think the revision through completely.  They have changed the pawns from cardboard forms that sit in a base to plastic figures that have their own built-in base.  The problem is that the instructions state that the pawns should be randomly placed in bases with times noted on the bottom of them (using stickers).  Not sure how you randomly assign a permanent sticker each time you play the game.  Elimination of the white bases for the pawns also has resulted in the loss of a die to play the game too.  I've purchased two of these now and both arrived with the same contents, so it seems to be a fault of the game (re)design, not an isolated packing issue.

author: Kindle Customer
title: difficult for kids
content: We still haven't figured out how to play tbis game. And it not for lack of trying. I wish the game maker would come out with a simple video explaining the rules because nobody in our home or several neighbors who borrowed it couldn't figure it out either

author: Joshua Moore
title: Great fun
content: Everything arrived perfectly.  We did not know that when you roll, you can move any character as the directions do not say that.  We got half-way through the game when I realized not moving the other two unused characters made no sense because we weren't rolling enough white squares to reveal a clue under them, and the game would never end without using them . . . So once we realized you move ANY character you want, that's when the game moved faster and more strategy came into play.  Kids loved it, as did I.  My 5 is a little naiive and needs help with deductive reasoning.  He played, but next time I think we will put him on a team.

content:
I love this game. And so do my kids.
But my 6 y/o doesn't fully understand it, so she gets so bored playing it, i totally recommend it for older kids (my 10 y/o loves it)

author: Sarah
title: My four year old loves this game
content: This is such a fun version of Clue!  My four year old can play it.  They love the fact that it's someone stealing the cake, they find it so hilarious.  We changed the rules a little bit in regards to finding a person, as you can only look under a person if you roll a white but we found we stalled out, not being able to progress as no one was rolling a white and we figured everything else out.  So we started rolling so we can land on a person and being able to see under them and rolling a white so see under any person.  Not sure if that was just left out of the instructions or not but way better and faster to play like that.  Our kids attention span isn't that long anyways so it worked so much better.

author: Jamie
title: My 5 yr old loves it
content: My daughter received this as a gift and she really likes it. I was pleasantly surprised to find that the Jr version didn't involve murder.

content: This was a gift

author: AP
title: Too complicated for little kids.
content: So complicated for young children. The original Clue was one of my favorites but this one, not so much.

author: Trevans
title: Fun game
content: I mean....it's Clue, without teaching innocent kids about how one would murder someone with a candlestick. Awesome.

author: Einat Fraiman
title: love this game
content: very easy to learn from 5 years old

author: JC Hertzler
title: Disappointed
content:
I wanted to introduce my child to Clue. I saw this and thought it would be perfect. I was surprised to find all this initial setup required (putting stickers on plastic game pieces, punching out cardboard to assemble other game pieces and having to try and read through the instructions to figure out what stickers go on what). Once we got past that hurdle, then we read the instructions for game play. I have no idea how any child would be able to play this game without adult supervision (even if they can read). We found the instructions to be confusing and decided to just go back to the old version of Clue where people are murdered by other people with actual weapons.
Please note, if you or anyone else playing the game is visually impaired you may find it difficult to determine the beverage that the cookie thief drank. The stickers are in color but quite small and the score sheet is printed in shades of grey.

author: Michelle S. Adams
title: The product came wrapped up in plastic wrap as if ...
content: The product came wrapped up in plastic wrap as if it had not been used before... BUT was missing a special die to which you were supposed to put stickers... and 6 white bases without which you cannot play the game.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Perfect for m y 5 and 7 year-olds!
content: My kids (age 5 and 7) enjoy playing Clue, but it's a little complicated--especially for the youngest. Clue, Jr. is perfect for them both! Game play is uncomplicated. The pre-made papers for checking off items you've seen is so simple and includes pictures, making it easy for my son to use since he can't yet read. I would definitely recommend this to anyone who wants the fun of Clue with less complexity (and violence--this is for kids, after all)!

author: Vanessa Avila
title: An awesome game to involve the lil ones
content: A great mini version of Clue to play with first graders.

author: kt
title: I have played it (my most favorite game growing up
content: I ordered this game to use in my elementary SpEd classroom. The kids were SOOOO EXCITED when I pulled it out to show them what we got!! It was a tad bit confusing to put the stickers on the chips when getting everything ready to play, but we finally figured it out. After that, it was GAME ON!! My students have never played the original Clue game, so this is a novelty to them! I have played it (my most favorite game growing up!), and, in my opinion, this one compares nicely!! The paper that each player uses to sort the clues out makes each player cross off the information that they discover while playing the game. So, in the end, they deduce who ate the cake, at what time, and what they drank with it. It's very simple to play once you run through a few dice rolls & use the instructions. My students picked it up and are LOVING IT!!! They're using skills (inferencing, drawing conclusions, predictions, critical thinking, and strategies) they didn't know how to do before we started. It's making a couple of them communicate more, and everyone is thoroughly enjoying themselves and their company.

author: Alana
title: Perfect
content: Great game to play with my 7 year old.  She's into mysteries and puzzles and this is perfect to play with her, even just 2 players.

author: Amazon Customer

I found a free online version of the adult game, and we had much more fun with it. If anyone knows how we're supposed to figure out who the thief is, please let me know!

author: shayyclark
title: Fun game for kids!

The junior version is more age appropriate than the murder mystery that I remember playing.  The kids love discovering "who ate the cake", "at what time" and with "what to drink".  The whole family will love it.

Def a great family night game with younger kids!

author: Brianne Mancini

author: Emily Cutler
title: Good game, kid approved.
content: It was a bit confusing on how to move and which ways, but my kids seem to love it. 5 and 8 year olds.

author: Rob Goblin
title: Eh...
content: My 5 year old recently got into board games so we have been making the rounds of the old favorites. He asked about Clue and we tried to use the regular version but it was over his head. So we purchased Clue JR as an entry level version for him. There's a set up that took me about 20 minutes and then about 30 more minutes of reading the rules. I had assumed the instructions would be intended for a 5 year old they are overly worded and make the entire process harder than it needs to be. I'm trying to set up a game, learn the game, teach the game and all while my child is insanely excited over me. Most Junior games we have tried have been very abbreviated and require little set up. While the game was fun it caused unneeded anxiety in the process. I would've had an easier time just making up some rules for the regular Clue game and just rolling with it.

author: CAMcMama
title: Fun, non-murderous Clue game.
content: This game is just as fun as the original, but I didn't want the murder part in my home for my kids.  They are trying to find out who ate the last piece of cake, with which drink, and at what time.  :-)  It is fun and we play it over and over.  My four year old is barely able to play it.  She is getting the hang of crossing off the things on the list when she sees them under the items on the board. She doesn't need to be able to read for this very much.

author: Stephanie Warlik
title: Fun game

author: Boomer Gal

content: I found the game confusing and tedious to assemble correctly.  I finally got it done (still not correctly I realized later), and played a round with my 5-year-old granddaughter.  She never did understand what was going on, and when I asked her if she wanted to play again, she said no.  Let's say this version ISN'T the old version which I loved.  Or maybe you just need to be old enough to play the original game to really enjoy the concept.

author: Elle
title: Missing pieces????
content:
The game looks terrific. We were so excited to play with it. It arrived sealed and crisp. But when we opened it up, it had no white tokens and no die.
:(  I've never bought a new board game and found pieces missing before. It's useless.

author: Apple
title: Kids love it
content: My kids got this game for Christmas and love playing it.  It can be played over and over.  I love the cute characters with the game.

author: Travis Illig
title: Great intro to Clue and deductive reasoning
content:
I picked this up for my eight-year-old and she loves it. It definitely plays a bit differently than original Clue. Instead of cards, you move tokens around the board and the clues are on the bottoms of the tokens. Land on a specific spot, you can look at the bottom (secretly) and mark info off your note pad.

There's less you can infer here. With regular clue, you can see what people have and what they don't based on who shows a card (or doesn't). With this kid's version, you pretty much have to see all the clues yourself in order to figure it out unless you want to make a total guess. That's not a bad thing, it's just less complicated and means games can go on maybe longer than you might anticipate.

The kiddo loves it, though, and it gets her thinking and interacting, which is good.

There are a couple of minor drawbacks that I didn't really deduct points on:

1. You don't move one specific character, you pick any character and move them. This may mean one player spends a turn or two trying to get a character to a specific spot and then some other player "steals" it and makes the final move to see the bottom of the character. You can address this with some "house rules" maybe or potentially consider it strategy - I can effectively stop you from looking at a character by "stealing" it and moving it away from the spot you want it.

2. The characters sit in these little white bases. Each base has the clue on the bottom. You switch up the bases (blindly) each game. However, it can be sort of tough to get the characters in the base, and if you don't get them in exactly they slip out easily, which can cause for some frustration mid-game.

3. It's pretty easy to knock the characters and other pieces over with little arms and hands reaching all over. If you knock one over, you see the bottom... and that's where the clue is. In some cases, "accidents" end up amounting to "cheating" because it reveals info that shouldn't have been revealed. Once is an accident, two or three times in the same game... hmmm....

In all, though, it's good. I can't wait until we graduate to the original Clue.

It’s one of those games that we don’t mind playing with her because it has some strategy involved and we can legitimately play to win (or lose) - and she has beat us fair and square quite a few times already. We figure that the game play for 3 players takes about 20-25 minutes, which is not too long but not too short either. I highly recommend this game for a family game night.

title: Disappointed in the Fun Level
content: Packaging was great, and delivery was fast. We were looking for a new game to play with our son, and thought this would be a fun game, but we were disappointed. The directions to play were somewhat confusing, and we had to constantly refer back to them because we were unsure about steps. Putting the correct labels and stickers on the plastic pieces was easy to do, but the directions were not perfectly clear. We played the game, and it was actually boring—not what we anticipated at all. Our son wanted to stop playing after just a couple minutes.

author: Austin Willis

author: Marisa Fox
title: Cute but more confusing than necessary
content:
I love Clue! I want to love Clue, Jr., but they made it more complicated than necessary. Monopoly Jr. rocks - they simplified it perfectly while still keeping the game intact.

First - the setup takes awhile - and the setup is kinda hard to do - think an older child or adult would have to help...each time the game is played.

Second - the game board could be more clean & simple. It's hard to look at - and the multiple spaces inside the rooms is unnecessary. I wish there were just basic blocks - instead of random footprints. And I wish that when you entered a room, you chose to land on a yellow or a white circle in each room. Period.

Third - I wish they included reusable laminated flip up cards with bigger, more clear pictures so you could more easily see the pictures and mark them off with a dry erase marker or washable marker.

This game has potential, but I was pretty disappointed at the details of the board and the play sheets. Who tested this? Huge red flags if you think a 5 - 7 year-old will be able to play it.

It's a fun game that the kids love to play, although my 5 year old does get bored and does something else. My 6 yr old does pretty good, gets distracted easy and have to keep telling them it's their turn, but kept playing til the end. Reccomend 6 or older depending how patient your child can be.

title: CLUE JUNIOR GAME - VERY DISAPPOINTING
content: I bought this game to play with our 4 & 6 year old grandsons.  My husband & I tried to play the game before playing it with our grandsons, and could  not make sense of it by following the instructions provided with the game.  We felt that something was missing with the instructions, so I went online and found instructions to this game and discovered that a section was missing with the instructions that were provided with the game.  The online instructions made more sense, but the game is still difficult to play.  I would NOT recommend this game.

author: Joshua Bruns
title: Outstanding kid version
content: I highly recommend this! Very high quality pieces and the rules are modified to work well for children.  Very well done.  My 6 year old is able to play easily by herself.  This is also a game that does not bore parents to tears. :)

author: Glenn
title: Four Stars
content: I think the age should be 6 instead of 5

author: rosepetal
title: Perfect! Read “Emily96” review too
content: Love this game and “Emily96”’s recommendations. Thank you for such a thorough review. We are loving your way of playing!!!

author: SUE
title: Not as good as the Adult Version of Clue
content: I bought this to play with grandkids.  The adult version is MUCH better.

author: JK
title: We bought regular clue for our 3 year old and ...
content: We bought regular clue for our 3 year old and taught her how to pay that. We saw this and then bought it, this game is more difficult then the original. The only use we get out of it is the character figures, we threw the game away.

author: Tyson
title: Ok Kids game...
content: Unfortunately it's not like real Clue, so my kids played it one time and now it sits on a shelf...

author: Bianca
title: 6 year old loves it
content: Fun game.

author: SuzyQ75
title: Fun Game for Grandkids
content: Harder to learn than regular Clue for a grandparent.

author: TD
title: Too tough for younger children....
content: Bought this hoping it would be a fun game to play with my 6yo boys as we love Monopoly Junior. Unfortunately this game was very hard to play with them as it was long and didn’t hold their attention and they had trouble tracking their clues without my help which meant I couldn’t really play against them fairly at that point. I would skip on this one. The deliver and purchase was fine, but just not for younger kids.

author: Mackenzie Rademaker
title: Missing pieces
content: Game arrived with sealed plastic, however not all the game pieces were in the box. Very disappointed as we are unable to use.

author: Stacey Poirier
title: Disappointed
content: Cheaply made. Disappointed.

author: Kelly N.
title: Cute game
content: Pretty neat game. I purchased it for my daughters second grade classroom for indoor winter recess since it can have up to 6 players. I let her read the directions and try to figure it out at first and she got the concept pretty well. I had to explain how to mark off people and items on the sheet and why it was so important but thats not a huge deal to miss the concept on. Fun game I'd say for average players age 6-8.

author: Jamie H
title: Family time
content: This is a great game for young kids, easy to set up, understanding of the rules and game play is simple.

author: Li W
title: Five Stars
content: Now if only the rest of my family got as excited as I do for this game.

author: Amanda
title: A little complex
content: The only reason I am giving this four stars is because it is a bit complex to teach my daughter. It is fun once you get the hang of it.

author: Cliente de Amazon
title: Fun
content: Fun
